education_text.0: Felten has done a variety of      Computer security computer security research, including groundbreaking work on carrying authentication and work on security related to the   In 1993, he joined the faculty of      Princeton University Princeton University in the department of computer science as an assistant professorCiting research he had undertaken with Christian Hicks and Peter Creath, two of his former students,          Felten testified that it was possible to remove Internet Explorer functionality from Windows without causing any problems with the operating systemCiting research he had undertaken with Christian Hicks and Peter Creath, two of his former students,          Felten testified that it was possible to remove Internet Explorer functionality from Windows without causing any problems with the operating systemAs part of a contest in 2000,      redirect    SDMI (Secure Digital Music Initiative) invited researchers and others to try to break the      Digital audio digital audio      watermark technologies that they had devisedOn September 13, 2006, Felten and graduate students Ariel Feldman and      redirect    Alex Halderman Alex Halderman discovered severe security flaws in a Diebold Election Systems (now      Premier Election Solutions Premier Election Solutions)      Voting machine voting machineIn early 2008, New Jersey election officials announced that they planned to send one or more      Sequoia Voting Systems Sequoia Advantage voting machines to Ed Felten and      Andrew Appel Andrew Appel (also of Princeton University) for analysisAfter examining Sequoia's machines, Felten and Appel indeed discovered grave problems with the accuracy of the machinesAfter examining Sequoia's machines, Felten and Appel indeed discovered grave problems with the accuracy of the machinesIn February 2008, Felten and his students were part of the team that discovered the      Cold boot attack cold boot attack, which allows someone with physical access to a computer to bypass operating system protections and extract the contents of its memoryIn November 2010, Felten was named the first Chief Technologist of the      Federal Trade Commission Federal Trade Commission,          for which he took a year leave of absence from Princeton University
